question: Watch it with Meyerling. Man's as mean and corrupt as they get. Cut his mother's throat if it'd get him a couple votes.
answer: Hey, Sam, look over there. Black and white smoke.

question: Damn. Likely that's an SOS. Have to pass on that lunch.
answer: We'll go with you.

question: No way can he get away with this. I'll be back by tonight. Ben Corbett?
answer: Yep. Afraid you have me at a disadvantage.

question: Kenai at the general store asked me to bring these. Didn't expect we'd already met.
answer: No big deal. We just got off on the wrong foot. What's your name?

question: Desmond.
answer: New to the country, kid?

question: Six months. Ecological study for Northland Oil.
answer: Ecology. Folks use that term for everything but what it means Now, why don't you get around to saying what you want. You wouldn't shoot anyone...

question: All this for laying traps on private land?
answer: You left a footprint at the Sportsmen's camp. Only pretty sight there, Ben, 'cause the two men you didn't shoot and mutilate died of exposure.

question: Christ if I shouldn't know better than to step in soft earth. I've seen footprints in the tundra a hundred years old.
answer: I got it from here. Thanks.

question: This is Sam Wilder, Marshal in Devil's Cauldron. Had some killings here. I got a suspect; be real nice if someone came and took him off my hands. Next plane's not coming 'til next Monday. This man's friends ain't gonna look favorably on his incarceration.
answer: Mind if I get some stuff from my kit? Sam, listen -- I shot to defend my man. Other guy drew first.

question: If that was all, fine. But carving him up, stranding the others, that's too fucking much. Is everything that walks, crawls, flies or swims fair game to you?
answer: I'll get loose before that plane comes.

question: Did you catch Corbett?
answer: Sure did. He was one of the trappers we rousted from the Haul Road.

question: Was there any trouble?
answer: He was sitting in a hot tub with a hooker.

question: Going after killers isn't the same as chasing poachers, Eric.
answer: Can't help myself. Corbett's type always pisses me off. Oh, I found this at the post office. Had your name on it.

question: Oh, sweetheart. It's beautiful!
answer: You were looking at it in the catalog. Don't know where you can wear it...

question: I'll wear it for you. And I can wear it when we go home. We won't be here forever.
answer: You make it sound like a prison sentence.

question: That's not what I meant.
answer: It's exactly what you meant.

question: Look, why get into this again. As long as it's working, let's leave it alone. It's been nice so far. We're together --
answer: -- Permanently?

question: I still can't believe I'm being financed by an oil company. Especially when they get a look at these pictures. Technology in the wilderness; not too pretty. What's that?
answer: I thought I should check our emergency transmitters. Avalanche season is coming.

question: Winter. Two straight months of night -- we may never get out of bed. Which would suit me fine.
answer: Prolonged darkness makes people crazy.

question: Not me. I'm equipped. Allow me to give you a practical demonstration of low-light infrared photography... High-tech in the wilderness. Gets me excited, too.
answer: Come here...

question: Does he have people?
answer: A daughter in Oregon.

question: Send him down to her. There's money in my duffel bag, back at his cabin.
answer: I better call in. Thought of everything, huh?

question: Surviving is what I know --
answer: -- Killing is what you know. Pack some food while I prep for the flight. I'm sure not gonna let him go.

question: ...Ben never sent a signal.
answer: Musta never got a chance to -more-

question: Meaning he'll need a plane.
answer: Closest planes for hire are here in Cache.

question: How long have you been up north?
answer: Six months.

question: Can't be. Too keen a sense of this place in your pictures.
answer: Six months this time. I was born in the Aleutians.

question: Your people Alaskan?
answer: My dad was a Navy doctor.

question: Knew you had no native blood, even with your dark hair. Blue eyes give you away. My wife had blue eyes.
answer: Had?

question: She's dead.
answer: Oh.

question: Had some good years. Met her in '66. She showed up one day in Coldfoot. No one knew her. One Sunday morning, she marched into a bar and announced she was available as a wife to the highest bidder. Didn't work out in three months, she'd return the money and leave, no hard feelings. My bid was eight thousand dollars. Beautiful girl.
answer: How did she..?

question: I was gone, in September, laying traplines. She went to our cache for some meat. Got mauled by a bear. Tore open her skull. -more- What about you -- why come back? Classy girl like you seems more suited to the finer things.
answer: That's why I left, moved to Washington. When I met Eric I was doing day shoots -- products and fashion, mostly. Pretty dull. Eric was teaching college, and then he got the job with Northland Oil. We wanted to stay together, so we talked them into funding some wilderness photography... and here I am.

question: -- Don't ever think you can buy Eric off, Mr. Corbett --
answer: -- Cheechako?

question: Outsider.
answer: Let's go.

question: Wait a second. Maybe you should drive him into Devil's Cauldron, let them decide what to do with him.
answer: Fairbanks is a three-hour flight. I'll be back by dinnertime. Be careful, okay?

question: How the hell were they smart enough to find us?
answer: Smart? Sure. That's why I'm sitting in this plane and they're down there blowing me kisses. Been driving long?

question: I needed a pilot's license to take the job here, so I got one in six weeks.
answer: That makes the flight more interesting. See the blood? Pack of wolves took down a moose. Greedy, gut-ripping sons of bitches. I'd kill the last wolf on earth, right in front of the President of the U.S. Stinking, cowardly predator, the wolf.

question: Sounds like professional jealousy.
answer: Hunting and trapping was a damn fine life. Me and Mitchell, Bob and LeMalle, we were teams. I'd always go with Mitchell. Good man, Mitchell. I'd let Bob worry about goddamn LeMalle. We'd hire a plane in October. On the way to a dirt airstrip somewhere, we'd drop supplies. We'd land, tell the pilot to come back for us a few days before Christmas. The idea was to get to the supplies before the bears did. Along the route we'd set our traps. Made our year's living in three months. Lot of times we didn't even have a landing strip. We'd set down on a plateau, like that one there. Yeah, that one's easy; you could glide right in... Hope you got your money's worth on those lessons.

question: Stay put!
answer: You got the belly to look me in the eye and pull the trigger?

question: Be no different than shooting a rabid dog. Next time you want to kill yourself, don't include me.
answer: I took the odds on getting down in one piece, and I made it. Now we're in my territory.

question: With light clothing and no supplies, this is nobody's territory.
answer: You sound like the tourists. Know-it-alls who read about survival in a magazine. Fuck you. You won't make it off this mountain.

question: Let's go.
answer: I'm not gonna carry you out of here.

question: That's right. You're not.
answer: Look, take these cuffs off. We need to work together.

question: Forget it. Last time I checked the flight plan, we were forty miles northeast of Devil's Cauldron. Southwest is that way. No sense waiting for a goddamn taxi. It'll be interesting, trying to build a fire without any wood.
answer: Welcome to the environment, Mr. Ecology. Out here, one mistake is all you get. Why in hell you care enough about me to die taking me in?

question: I don't plan on dying. We'll stop here, dig out a snow shelter.
answer: Snow shelter. Okay. You dig. I'll have a little sit-down. Even in the drifts, this snow's too powdery to make a shelter. When you're done jerking around, reach down the back of my coat. Still quite a hike to Devil's Cauldron. Days. A long stretch to go without sleep, my friend. You can hide behind that pistol for now, but take your eyes off me long enough to sneeze --

question: -- Turn around.
answer: Ice is too thin -- you can see the water moving underneath.

question: We're not sitting here 'til November. There's a cargo plane coming to Devil's Cauldron in four days, and I'm putting you on it.
answer: We get wet, we freeze to death in a couple hours.

question: I've been on ice like this when I was a kid, skating. Spread your weight, keep moving. Go on.
answer: Be my guest.

question: Wait 'til I'm across! Most dangerous thing in the world
answer: It wasn't my idea to crash the plane.

question: Let's camp. There's grayling under this ice. I'll snare some for dinner.
answer: We've got another two hours of daylight.

question: I've been trying to raise you on the shortwave for two days.
answer: Have you talked to Eric?

question: I have not, but I very much want to. What do you know about the trouble in Devil's Cauldron?
answer: I was hoping you had some news --

question: -- Get this straight
answer: -- Corbett's a killer.

question: I don't care if Ben Corbett makes meatloaf out of nuns and babies, he's not your concern. Understood? What happened here?
answer: The radio's on the fritz.

question: Where'd you say Eric is?
answer: Somewhere along the pipeline.

question: What about that hotheaded marshal, Sam Wilder? I heard he was in the middle of this mess.
answer: Sam? We haven't seen him.

question: Really. I thought maybe that was his snowmobile outside. By the way -- your truck also 'on the fritz?'
answer: Why?

question: Just gather birch. It'll smoke like hell, but it'll burn green. I need your pocket knife. I have to eat, too. Damn lucky this storm didn't blow down when we were on those baldheaded mountains. It continues, we better stay put.
answer: It could blow over tomorrow, too.

question: I'm still figuring
answer: I just want this over with.

question: Where in hell Meyerling dig you up?
answer: You know Meyerling?

question: Sure. The People's Friend. Kiss your ass with precision if there's a vote in it. Always eat your meat raw when the weather's cold. Does you more good, long as the entrails look clean.
answer: I'll hold onto that.

question: Sure love to know where you fit in up here.
answer: I'm here to do my job.

question: You want to fool yourself about that bullshit job, fine. Damn shame you have to drag your girlfriend along. You think a woman like that will be happy making moose stew for a man -more-
answer: Don't fucking insult me.

question: Folks come to Alaska for a real short list of reasons
answer: Yeah?

question: There's a cabin, maybe twenty miles south of here.
answer: Too bad we're heading west.

question: There's a snowmobile. Inside a day we could be on the Yukon. I got money there. Remember that five thousand? Make it ten. Be smart. Take it and walk away.
answer: You don't get it, do you? Stop! hobbles after him, CUSSING bitterly to himself.

question: Nothing personal. Just wanted to see what you'd do. Have to get these wet things off.
answer: You're not going to slow us down! Keep moving!

question: Inside of three hours you'd be dragging my dead carcass.
answer: Stay awake! You want to go hypothermic?

question: If that means freeze my balls off, no thanks. I'll be okay. Told you I'm fine!
answer: How many do you see?

question: What?! Fuck off. Save yourself.
answer: You don't feel cold?

question: It's a spring day...
answer: Wake up, goddammit! You've got classic hypothermia -- crankiness, fatigue, can't feel your coldness. Worst thing you can do is fade out. One more thing -- this doesn't mean we're going steady. Stay still.

question: Where's my ELT?
answer: Emergency transmitter? All your gear is back at Wilder's.

question: You got one?
answer: It was blown up with the plane.

question: Too bad. We'd be out of here in a few hours.
answer: How? Nobody this far north monitors that frequency until avalanche season. Besides, I'm surprised a tough guy like you uses fancy electronics.

question: I'm surprised a flat-ender like you knows cold-weather remedies.
answer: Read a lot of adventure stories when I was a kid...

question: I'm hungry. Go kill me some dinner.
answer: An appetite. Maybe you won't die after all.

question: Used to see the natives eating roots when I was a kid in Nome.
answer: Nome? I figure you'd be a whaler, coming from there.

question: Told that's what our old man was. Planned on going to sea, me and Bob, 'til I read Jack London. Started trapping when I was ten. Mailed the furs to Sears. Eight bucks for a skunk, three for a muskrat. That was fine money.
answer: Killing wildlife not good enough anymore, so you go on to bigger and better things.

question: You got a knack for seeing things the way you want to see them. Don't judge me. You're a joke, coming here from a fucked-up culture, telling us what to do!
answer: Yeah, it is fucked up -- but it's not too late to keep that from happening here.

question: All you do is keep folks from working the land, living like they're meant to. You don't understand shit! Trappers, hunters -- we're part of the environment. Who's protecting us? I've seen plenty like you. So -more-
answer: What do you know about people? You live like an animal! A savage goddamn throwback like you belongs out here, as far away from the rest of us as possible.

question: I'm real sad you don't approve of me. Tell me what I should do, Professor. You got all the answers. I shouldn't hunt? Fine, I'll just phone up and have a salad delivered.
answer: Don't push me..!

question: What makes you so sure my boys won't be waiting for us?
answer: They think you're in Fairbanks. If not, they still won't find you before the plane comes tomorrow.

question: Don't bet on it.
answer: I already have.

question: You don't know how true that is.
answer: We'll wait here until nightfall. No fire, no tarp.

question: Didn't mean it, you being a coward. You're a lot of things,
answer: Maybe...maybe not. I'll tell you what scares me -- stumbling through life, like an ordinary jerk. That's why I want to work on the front lines, where what I do means something. Soon as I got here, I realized my job was bullshit. Oil company propaganda. I was ready to leave, then I thought screw it, I'll outsmart them, do the work anyway. I don't know anymore. Maybe I am fooling myself. That's what I'm afraid of most of all.

question: My guess is he's loose and heading for Chukfoktulik. He'll need supplies; that's the closest settlement without a lawman.
answer: I ain't gonna leave a seven- hundred-dollar Remington behind.

question: What you gonna do with it? Large bore's for shit on small game.
answer: Not in the right hands it ain't. Thought that door was open last night...

question: You don't mind me saying, Mr. Desmond, you look like hell.
answer: Have you heard anything from the girl staying with me, Anne Marie?

question: Not a damn thing. What's going on? Mr. Meyerling was here, all steamed up, looking for you.
answer: Look, Neff, I've got Ben Corbett with me --

question: -- Here?! Where's Wilder?
answer: Back at my place... he, uh, broke his leg.

question: If Corbett's men find out --
answer: -- I'm putting him on the plane to Fairbanks, eleven tomorrow.

question: Jiminy Christmas. What do you want from me?
answer: Corbett ruined my two-way. Go to my place on the Haul Road, tell Anne Marie I'm okay and to sit tight.

question: I'll go at dawn.
answer: Thanks. Don't tell anyone you saw me.

question: Why the smirk?
answer: Bet I could make some money turning Ben Corbett in. Maybe more for lettin' him loose. I was up in my cache. Saw the Northland man come talk to you.

question: You're out of your greedy goddamn mind.
answer: Corbett coming here stinks of trouble. We should make the best of it before it turns around and bites us in the ass.

question: Talk to that good-looking girl of yours?
answer: You broke the radio, remember?

question: I'm sure she's fine. Seemed like a clever kid. You were real resourceful out there. Got me thinking of this perimeter man, froze all his fingers one winter. So he hacked the tips off and sharpened the exposed bones. Gets along better than ever. Yeah, maybe I underestimated you.
answer: I liked you better frozen. You didn't talk so much.

question: You're damn lucky, glimpsing this country before it's ruined, gone for good. You saw wonders you'd only dreamed of. That alone makes you different than the sorry bastards back where you came from, because you have dreamt them. Remember that demon in the gut? Sometimes it's nothing more than wondering if the so-called civilized life has bred the balls and brains out of you. That's what you want out of this, isn't it?
answer: All I want want is you in jail --

question: ...I won't let a killer walk!
answer: Alleged killer.

question: What does this matter to you?
answer: You can't see past your lousy little assignment, sniffing around the pipeline. The few voters there are in this district look up to Corbett, and I'm not about to alienate them.

question: I should release Corbett because you want some votes?
answer: This miserable wilderness is a state of the union. Policy's made here the same way as in the civilized world

question: Just stay out of my face until I'm gone! Emergency transmitter? What happened to signal mirrors or two-tone smoke fires?
answer: Lets us watch each other's backs over a wide area. Only thing messed me up this time was getting arrested in the baths. ELT was in my duffel bag, not around my neck where it should've been.

question: No way they'll find you on a five-minute signal. And no way -more-
answer: They haven't disappointed me yet. Flashbomb, eh?

question: I need to rent a cabin.
answer: What's the problem with Sam Wilder's place?

question: Will you rent me a cabin, or not?
answer: Pretty clever

question: -- Here's a hundred dollars. And if you or anyone else will back me up on this --
answer: -- Forget it. And try not to bleed on my throw rugs. Why do this?

question: Eric! Why aren't you in Fairbanks? Oh, Christ, sweetheart. Four days! I thought you were dead, or worse.
answer: You can't stay here. Go back to the Turtle. I'll meet you back there in a few hours.

question: What's going on?
answer: I'll tell you everything later.

question: Where's Corbett?
answer: Here. A transport plane is due at eleven. Once I put him on it, it's all over.

question: So what's the problem?
answer: There isn't one, unless Corbett's men get here before the plane does.

question: Let the people here handle it. It's their marshal Corbett killed!
answer: Please, Anne Marie, you being here only complicates things.

question: I'm staying.
answer: Take the snowmobile, park it behind Wilder's cabin.

question: Take the snowmobile, park it behind Wilder's cabin.
answer: I was just on my way to your ladyfriend's, but I guess she found you.

question: Yeah. Sorry I barked at you last night.
answer: I'm the one should be sorry... Goddamn Kenai, always out for a score. I never should've let him go over there.

question: I'd sure like that favor you offered a while back.
answer: Look, Mr. Desmond, I didn't count on it turning this ugly.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Bastards killed Sam, you think they won't kill the rest of us?

question: There'll be three, four men at the most. I have some backup, nothing will happen.
answer: I'm real sorry. In a while, you're gone from this country. But we live here. No one wants to mix it up with those hombres.

question: You don't care enough about Sam to --
answer: -- Sam Wilder was my cousin. He's why I came to Alaska. All his letters, saying what a paradise it is. But me ending up dead won't do Sam a lick of good.

question: What about you, Neff?
answer: Well... two of the trappers are down already --

question: -- One left; three of us. Let's finish it.
answer: What about Eric Desmond?
